contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} [[Image:Wapping prospect of whitby 1.jpg|thumb|The Prospect of Whitby seen from the Thames foreshore. (January 2006)]] '''The Prospect of Whitby''' is a historic [[public house]] on the banks of the [[river Thames|Thames]] at [[Wapping]] in the [[London Borough of Tower Hamlets]]. It lays claim to being the site of the oldest riverside [[tavern]], dating from around 1520. It was formerly known as the ''Devil’s Tavern'', on account of its dubious reputation. Before that it was officially called "The Pelican". All that remains from the building’s earliest period is the 400 year old stone floor. In former times it was a meeting place for [[sailor]]s, [[smuggler]]s, cut-throats and [[footpad]]s. [[Hugh Willoughby (sea captain)|Sir Hugh Willoughby]] sailed from here in 1533 in a disastrous attempt to discover the [[North-East Passage]] to [[China]]. In the 17th century, it became the hostelry of choice of "[[Hanging]]" [[Judge Jeffreys]], scourge of the [[Monmouth Rebellion]]. He lived nearby and a noose hangs by a window, commemorating his custom. He was chased by anti-Royalists into the nearby ''Town of Ramsgate'', captured and taken to the [[Tower of London|Tower]] for his own safety. According to legend, criminals would be tied up to the posts at low tide and left there to drown when the tide came in. [[Execution Dock]] was actually by Wapping Old Stairs and generally used for pirates.<ref name=brit><cite>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.asp?compid=45082 ''The Thames Tunnel, Ratcliff Highway and Wapping,'' Old and New London: Volume 2 (1878), pp. 128-37] Retrieved 29 March 2007</cite></ref> Views from the pub were sketched by both [[J. M. W. Turner|Turner]] and [[James McNeill Whistler|Whistler]]. Writers [[Charles Dickens]] and [[Samuel Pepys]] are known to have paused to sup here.<ref name=brit/> Following a fire in the early 19th century, the tavern was rebuilt and renamed ''The Prospect of Whitby'', after a Tyne [[Collier (ship type)|collier]] that used to berth next to the pub. The Prospect was [[listed building|listed Grade II]] in December 1950.<ref>{{IoE|206332}} accessed 9 December 2008</ref> [[Image:Prospect of Whitby (street view).JPG|thumb|Right|The Prospect of Whitby, street view]] On the opposite side of the road ([[Wapping Wall]]) is the [[Wapping Hydraulic Power Station]], now an arts centre and restaurant. The public house features briefly in an episode of ''[[Only Fools And Horses]]''. When Uncle Albert goes missing in one episode, Del Boy and Rodney travel around London looking for him. [[Nicholas Lyndhurst]] is shown in one scene walking out of the pub. There is also a scene from the 1956 film ''[[D-Day the Sixth of June]]'' starring [[Robert Taylor (actor)|Robert Taylor]] and [[Richard Todd]] where Taylor's character is seen with [[Dana Wynter]]'s character having drinks together during the [[Second World War]] in London. In the comic book ''[[The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen]]'', [[Mina Harker]] pauses in front of the public house and says it brings back memories. She is referring to the beaching of the ''Demeter'' at [[Whitby]] in the novel ''[[Dracula]]''. This pub is also featured in ''[[Jean Bruller|Vercors]]'''s novel Les Animaux dénaturés (translated variously into English as You Shall Know Them, Borderline, and The Murder of the Missing Link). ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.pubs.com/main_site/pub_details.php?pub_id=183 Pubs.com information] {{coord|51|30|25.56|N|0|3|4.15|W|type:landmark_scale:3000|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prospect Of Whitby}} [[Category:Grade II listed buildings in London]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tower Hamlets]] [[Category:Public houses in London]] [[Category:Restaurants in London]] [[Category:History of Tower Hamlets]] [[Category:Buildings and structures on the River Thames]] [[Category:Visitor attractions in Tower Hamlets]] [[Category:Grade II listed public houses]] [[Category:16th-century establishments in England]]
